misconceptions.name: Implemented the wrong problem (distance instead of grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points instead of reading a numeric grade (0–100) and printing the corresponding letter grade. This indicates a misunderstanding or misreading of the problem requirements: no single grade is read, no conditional ranges for A–F are checked, and no letter grade is output.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the task is to calculate the Euclidean distance between two points given (x1, y1) and (x2, y2), not to map a numeric grade to a letter grade.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read one numeric grade value between 0 and 100 from the user and then use conditional statements to determine and print the correct letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, and y2 instead of a single grade
Program calculates a square root expression involving (x2 - x1) and (y2 - y1)
Program never uses conditionals to check grade ranges 90–100, 80–89, etc.
Program never prints a letter grade (A, B, C, D, F)
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely misinterpretation of the assignment instructions or copying a solution for a different problem (distance between two points) rather than implementing the requested grade calculator.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and identify the exact inputs and outputs required. Replace the distance-related inputs and formula with code that reads a single grade value and uses if/else-if/else conditions to decide which letter grade to print.
related_concepts: Designing conditionals based on numeric ranges
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is clearly solving a different textbook-style problem (distance between two points) and does not contain any elements of a grade calculator, such as grade variables, range checks, or letter outputs.

evidence.note: The program reads four coordinates and computes the Euclidean distance instead of reading a single numeric grade and mapping it to a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Failure to address assignment requirements
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for calculating the distance between two points, a completely different task, instead of writing the required Grade Calculator program (Q3).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the submitted code fulfills the requirements of the grade calculator assignment, likely due to submitting the wrong file or misreading the question prompt.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading one numeric grade (0-100) and implementing conditional logic (if/else) to print a corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Class name does not match assignment purpose (DistanceBetweenPoints instead of GradeCalculator)
Input asks for coordinates instead of a grade
Code performs mathematical calculations (distance formula) instead of conditional logic (grading scale)
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of problem requirements or submitting code for an unrelated assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt (Q3 Grade Calculator) carefully and submit the correct code that implements conditional logic to assign letter grades based on the numeric input.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is demonstrably for a different problem (Euclidean Distance calculation) and contains none of the logic required by Q3 (Grade Calculator).

evidence.note: The class name indicates the code is for a different problem (Distance Between Points).
The input section reads four coordinate values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of the single numeric grade required for Q3.
The core logic calculates the distance formula, not grade ranges.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student has implemented a completely different program (distance between two points) instead of the required grade calculator program.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a distance calculation problem, not a grade classification problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires a grade calculator that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on specified ranges.
symptoms: Program reads x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates instead of a grade
Program calculates Euclidean distance instead of determining letter grades
No conditional logic for grade ranges (A: 90-100, B: 80-89, etc.)
Output is a distance value, not a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Fundamental misunderstanding or misreading of the problem statement. The student may have implemented a previous exercise or confused this assignment with another one.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem carefully. You need to: (1) Read ONE grade value (0-100), (2) Use if-else statements to check which range it falls into, (3) Print the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Complete certainty. The submitted code solves an entirely different problem (distance calculation) with no relation to the grade calculator requirements.

evidence.note: The program reads coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade value.

evidence.snippet:
System.out.printf("The distance of the two points is %f%n",
                Math.sqrt(Math.pow(x2 - x1, 2) + Math.pow(y2 - y1, 2)));
evidence.note: Calculates and outputs Euclidean distance instead of determining a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem instead of the requested grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The submission implements a distance-between-two-points calculator (reading x1, y1, x2, y2 and computing a Euclidean distance) rather than the required grade-to-letter-grade converter. As a result, none of the rubric requirements are addressed: it does not read a single numeric grade, does not use conditionals to check grade ranges, and does not output a letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and computes the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 and use conditional logic to map that numeric grade to a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges, then print the letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, and y2 instead of a single numeric grade.
No conditional statements or Boolean range checks for grade intervals (90-100, 80-89, etc.).
Output reports a numeric distance instead of a letter grade such as A, B, C, D, or F.
Class name and output text clearly indicate a distance calculation task rather than a grade calculator.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem requirements, likely confusing this assignment with a different textbook or lab exercise about computing the distance between two points.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment carefully and restate it in your own words before coding. Identify: (1) the exact input the program should read (a single numeric grade), (2) the required processing (checking which grade range it falls into using if/else), and (3) the exact output format (a letter grade). Then design and implement an if/else-if chain that covers all numeric ranges and prints the appropriate letter.
related_concepts: Mapping problem descriptions to program structure
Range checking with relational and logical operators
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure (inputs, calculations, and output) matches a standard distance formula problem and does not overlap at all with the described grade calculator requirements.

evidence.note: The code reads coordinates for two points and computes a Euclidean distance instead of reading a single numeric grade and mapping it to a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misinterpretation of Assignment Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a completely different programming problem (calculating the distance between two points) instead of the required Grade Calculator problem. This indicates a fundamental misunderstanding or failure to read the prompt for Q3.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the assignment required calculating the distance between two points, or perhaps they accidentally submitted code from a different task or copied an irrelevant functional template.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment (Q3) required reading a single numeric grade and determining the corresponding letter grade using conditional logic (if/else).
symptoms: Code implements an irrelevant function (distance calculation)
Input prompts ask for coordinates instead of a grade
Output calculation uses `Math.sqrt` and `Math.pow` instead of grade comparison logic
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to align the implemented solution with the requirements of Q3.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully review the assignment instructions for Q3 (Grade Calculator) and remove all functionality related to distance calculations. Focus on reading a single integer input and using `if-else if-else` statements to check the numeric ranges against the specified letter grades.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code calculates Euclidean distance, which is unequivocally not the Grade Calculator functionality required by the prompt and rubric.

evidence.note: The entire code implements a distance calculator, which is unrelated to the Grade Calculator problem Q3.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student has fundamentally misunderstood the assignment. Instead of writing a grade calculator program that reads a numeric grade (0-100) and outputs a letter grade, they have written a program that calculates the distance between two points in a 2D coordinate system.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they should write a program that reads two coordinate points (x1, y1, x2, y2) and calculates the Euclidean distance between them using the formula: distance = √((x2-x1)² + (y2-y1)²)
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade (0-100) and use conditional logic (if/else or switch statements) to determine and output the corresponding letter grade: A (90-100), B (80-89), C (70-79), D (60-69), or F (below 60).
symptoms: Program uses Scanner to read four decimal inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade value
Program calculates distance using Math.sqrt() and Math.pow() instead of implementing grade range conditionals
Output displays Euclidean distance instead of a letter grade
No boolean logic or conditional statements for grade determination
Completely different problem domain (coordinate geometry vs. grade classification)
misconceptions.root_cause: The student did not carefully read or understand the assignment specification. They may have completed a different programming exercise and submitted it accidentally, or they confused this assignment with another problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment requirements carefully. Start over with a fresh approach: (1) Read a single integer/double grade from the user, (2) Use if-else or switch statements to implement the grade scale, (3) Output the appropriate letter grade. Test with the sample input (85 → B) to verify correctness.
related_concepts: Boolean logic and conditional statements (if/else, switch)
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence because the evidence is unmistakable: the student's program solves a completely different problem. The problem statement clearly specifies a grade calculator, but the code implements distance calculation. There is no overlap between the required functionality and the submitted code.

evidence.note: Student reads two coordinate values instead of reading a single numeric grade (0-100)

evidence.snippet:
System.out.printf("The distance of the two points is %f%n",
        Math.sqrt(Math.pow(x2 - x1, 2) + Math.pow(y2 - y1, 2)));
evidence.note: Program calculates Euclidean distance using distance formula instead of implementing grade-to-letter mapping logic
Class name 'DistanceBetweenPoints' indicates the student is solving a coordinate distance problem, not a grade calculator problem
